{{about|the cartoonist|the Irish singer|Brian McFadden (singer)}} {{Infobox comics creator | bgcolour = #6495ED | name = Brian McFadden | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1984}}<ref name=Beat>{{cite web|url=http://www.comicsbeat.com/2011/06/24/editorial-cartoonist-brian-mcfadden-moves-to-the-new-york-times |website=[[ComicsBeat.com]] |title=Editorial cartoonist Brian McFadden moves to the New York Times |date=2011-06-24 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111124064954/http://www.comicsbeat.com/2011/06/24/editorial-cartoonist-brian-mcfadden-moves-to-the-new-york-times |archivedate=November 24, 2011 }}</ref> | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[United States|American]] | field = [[Cartoonist]] | training = [[Mechanical engineering]] | movement = | works = ''[[Big Fat Whale]]'' | patrons = | influenced by = [[Matt Groening]] | influenced = | awards = | website = http://brianmcfadden.org }}
'''Brian McFadden''' is an [[United States|American]] [[cartoonist]] who started on [[GeoCities]] in 2001,<ref>{{cite news|author=Goldfond, Joshua|title=‘The Bamboo Online Interview: Brian McFadden, NY Times Cartoonist & Creator of the "Big Fat Whale" online comic strip|url=http://www.thebambooonline.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=109:a-conversation-with-brian-mcfadden-ny-times-cartoonist|accessdate=April 8, 2012|publisher=The Bamboo Online}}</ref> created '''''Big Fat Whale''''', and became a featured artist at ''[[The New York Times]]'' in 2011.<ref name=WashingtonPost>{{cite news|author=Cavna, Michael|title=New York Times Debut: Alt-cartoonist Brian McFadden revels in paper’s first Sunday Review slot|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/comic-riffs/post/new-york-times-debut-thrilled-alt-cartoonist-brian-mcfadden-on-landing-the-papers-first-sunday-review-slot/2011/06/27/AGCmWFnH_blog.html|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=June 26, 2011|accessdate=April 8, 2012}}</ref>
==Personal life== As of June 2011, McFadden was 27 years old and lived in [[Massachusetts]].<ref name=Beat /> At a young age, McFeddan was influenced by [[Matt Groening]]'s alternative comic ''[[Life in Hell]]''.<ref name=WashingtonPost />
==''Big Fat Whale''== ''Big Fat Whale'' was a weekly [[webcomic]] both written and illustrated by McFadden. The comic started on October 16, 2001, in a form which the cartoonist described as "terrible, even by webcomic standards."<ref name="Big Fat Whale History">[http://www.bigfatwhale.com/history.html "Big Fat Whale History"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070704223403/http://www.bigfatwhale.com/history.html |date=July 4, 2007 }}</ref> Eventually, the strip improved.
The strip began its print run in [[Boston, Massachusetts|Boston's]] monthly publication ''[[Editorial Humor]]'' in 2002. However, the publication went out of business and the strip stayed on the web for almost a year.<ref name="Big Fat Whale History" /> In February 2004, ''Big Fat Whale'' was picked up by ''[[Cleveland Free Times]]'' and later by ''[[The Boston Phoenix]]''.<ref name="Big Fat Whale History" /> ''Big Fat Whale'' was included in [[Ted Rall|Ted Rall's]] [[Attitude 3: The New Subversive Online Cartoonists]].
==At ''The New York Times''== McFadden described being chosen as being a featured artist in ''[[The New York Times]]'' as being "plucked from some sandlot and dropped into a [[Major League Baseball|Major League]] stadium." The online newspaper was reinventing its Week in Review" section in May 2011, and [[Aviva Michaelov]] asked McFadden personally to join the section’s opening-debut roster. McFadden has been producing a weekly strip since; though he has stated to get a lot of leeway, McFeddan needs to get his scripts approved by mid-week so that he has enough time for his editing process.<ref name=WashingtonPost />
McFadden is supposed to give the section a "younger perspective".<ref name=Beat />
